text:
God, he is so mad at me right now. He is mad at me for saving his life. 

And he's gonna feel different tomorrow. And his feelings are valid. This is something that's happening to him as much as it's happening to us. I have to keep reminding myself.

This is silliness. The term in law—this law, specifically, as well as the immigration statutes in general—is "alien." 

Even Justice Breyer's dissent uses it because, y'know, that's the legal term for individuals subject to this law and lawsuit.

text:
In his complaint, Rep. Nunes claims that mockery on Twitter by just two accounts suppressed his margin of victory in his latest election.

That, in itself, is an astonishing claim. The Devin Nunes' cow account had only about 1,200 followers at the time the suit was filed.

text: Lawgeeks, a copy of the West Virginia AG's civil suit against the Wheeling-Charleston Diocese alleging violations of state consumer protection laws is here: https://ago.wv.gov/Documents/Diocese%20complaint.PDF …

text:
There's an interesting idea. West Virginia's AG is suing the Wheeling-Charleston Diocese under state consumer protection laws for knowingly employing pedophiles and failing to conduct background checks. 

The complaint has been filed in state court.

text: This is a very odd way to say SCOTUS sided with four other circuits against the Ninth Circuit's decision restraining DHS' statutory authority to detain certain criminal aliens.

text: I think only Alito, Roberts, and Kavanaugh joined that part of the opinion.
author: gabrielmalor

text: Tucked into SCOTUS' statutory interpretation decision today is this prudential consideration of whether Congress could have intended that certain criminal aliens not be detained without bond due to "local resistance" to ICE detainer requests. https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/18pdf/16-1363_a86c.pdf …
author: gabrielmalor

text:
(1) Democrats are still conflating the no-fly list with the terrorist watch list. These are different things.
(2) Neither the no-fly list nor the terrorist watch list were meant to adjudicate individual rights.
(3) Both lists have been used against Muslims without due process.

text:
And if the person in front of you is an asshole and crowds you, that doesn't mean you have license to be a jerk to the person behind you. 

This isn't the fuggin' transitive property. Be good if you're good.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
I don't get this thing where otherwise reasonable people don't know that you shouldn't crowd other people simply because you can. 

This isn't that hard. If there's nobody seated behind you, by all means, recline. If there is, be a decent human being. Not hard.
author: gabrielmalor

text: Hey, it was very friendly! I never even cursed once. And I never even said that Rep. Nunes has the intellectual and moral capacity of a peanut!
author: gabrielmalor

text: Anyway. Enjoy the circus. I intend to.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Quote: "If they stuck that entire complaint in the feeder and did black and white, the images of screen grabs would look like hell and not be deemed 'clear and reproducible.'" 

So the clerk would have to sort out the screen grabs and do those separate. That takes more time.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Alright, so to add to this thread, I was curious about how long it would actually take a clerk to open Nunes' case, so I — get this — asked one. 

And they said the screen grabs in the complaint will mean the clerk can't just scan it as usual.
author: gabrielmalor

text: *rubs temples*
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Rep. Nunes says today's lawsuit is "the first of many."

Nunes says "we're actually going after Twitter first" because "they are the main proliferator, and they spread this fake news and this slanderous news."
author: gabrielmalor

text: ZING
author: gabrielmalor

text: Here, opening the case generates the case number. And like I said, if the complaint came in late afternoon, it probably hasn't even been opened yet.
author: gabrielmalor

text: Anyway, I wouldn't go down the "is this a head fake?" route, guys.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
And, technically, on a non-emergency civil filing, there isn't actually a deadline for opening the case and scanning the complaint. 

But clerks usually stay pretty diligent on this, 'cause otherwise the cases just start piling up.
author: gabrielmalor

text: If reporter is correct and it was filed late in the afternoon, that explains why it's not in the system yet. One of the deputy clerks would have to open the case, then scan the documents. Stuff that comes in late afternoon wouldn't be opened and scanned until at least tomorrow.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Indeed, the complaint draft obtained by Fox News was almost certainly obtained from Nunes' office. 

If it had been filed, it would be a scanned copy from OCRA. (Virginia circuits don't have e-filing. Even if it were filed today, it's unlikely it would've been scanned in yet.)
author: gabrielmalor

text: Not sure when that happened.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Yes, frustratingly, the complaint never specifies *which* were the fighting words. 

That's one of the reasons I think this is not well-pleaded.
author: gabrielmalor

text: Anywhooo, I appreciate the kind words, guys, but I express no opinion on the ultimate outcome here. Defamation/insult and, er, negligent defamation (???) isn't my area of law.

text: I can't imagine Rep. Nunes has managed to serve the anonymous mean meme accounts yet.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Nunes filed in Henrico County, Virginia (which is where Twitter has a service address), but, of course, the defendants could try and remove it to federal court if they wish.

Virginia has an anti-SLAPP law. It is not a very good one tho.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Almost all of these aren't false statements of fact. It's counterproductive, I would think, to provide the public with a hyperconcentrated list of insults that by your own admission really, really bother you. 

*Note: Nunes is also suing for insulting words/fighting words.
author: gabrielmalor

text: In fact, the complaint specifically objects to a Mair tweet that is simply "HOLY CRAP" followed by the headline from the Fresno Bee and a link to the article. That ain't gonna work.
author: gabrielmalor

text: The only defamations specifically alleged to be from Mair in the suit (it claims there are others, but doesn't specify them; see prior not well-pleaded comment) involve mentions of the winery investment and Fresno Bee story.
author: gabrielmalor

text: I had vaguely recalled this Nunes winery investment business, but had forgotten all the details. The Fresno Bee reported on it in a piece headlined: "A yacht, cocaine, prostitutes: Winery partly owned by Nunes sued after fundraiser event."
author: gabrielmalor

text: fanks
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Bah. The ask is $250 million compensatory and $350k punitive. Thanks for the corexx, guys. 

(I was told there would be no math.)
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Para 35: "The ability to use Twitter is a vital part of modern citizenship." "Twitter is essential for an individual to . . . engage in any level of political organizing in modern America." 

Para 59: the court should order Twitter to permanently suspend Liz Mair's account.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
This, however, is not a well-written pleading. Quote: "As part of its agenda to squelch Nunes' voice. . . *Twitter did absolutely nothing.*"

(Presumably, they mean Twitter did nothing despite a duty to do something.)
author: gabrielmalor

text:
This is a tweet from one of the meme accounts that Nunes objects to. The account has been suspended. 

According to the complaint, Twitter's failure to police this image, among other things, caused Nunes "extreme pain and suffering."
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Also, the complaint seems to be pretending not to know what a taint team is. Or a pun. 

Anyway, I thought that one was funny, so here you go.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Here's the complaint. A lot of these don't sound like false statements of fact to me. Loootta opinion stuffed in here from, I don't even know how to describe them: meme accounts? mean accounts? 

Gonna take a while to sort through. https://www.scribd.com/document/402297422/Nunes-Complaint-3-18-19 …
author: gabrielmalor

text: Oh, excuse me he's asking for $250 million, according to the complaint.
author: gabrielmalor

text: Suing Twitter and Liz Mair for $200 million is exactly what I'd expect a ding dong like Devin Nunes to do. In the lawsuit he claims that Twitter's failure to police mean memes, among other things, caused him "extreme pain and suffering." GTFOOH, ding dong.
author: gabrielmalor

text: "Use your name, you coward!" has the other passengers on this train wondering if I just coughed or snorted.

text:
11th Cir. rejects appeal of Alabama, which tried to prevent journalists from obtaining the state's lethal injection protocol, which the state had used in litigation. 

Court concludes it became a judicial document subject to the common law right of access. http://media.ca11.uscourts.gov/opinions/pub/files/201812402.pdf …
author: gabrielmalor

text: The company did not have a written anti-harassment or anti-discrimination policy.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
8th Cir. upholds jury award of one dollar in compensatory damages and $250,000 in punitive damages for hostile work environment claim, in part bc of the repugnance of activity and employer's failure to correct. 

Also awards attorneys fees.
https://ecf.ca8.uscourts.gov/opndir/19/03/182297P.pdf …
author: gabrielmalor

text: The maj. op. notes that this is the third speedy trial case to come out of the WDNY in two years.
author: gabrielmalor

text: 2d Cir.: delay of five years and eight months, largely the result of prosecutors' pushing off the determination whether to pursue the death penalty and the addition of new charges two years after indictment, violated defendants' speedy trial right. http://www.ca2.uscourts.gov/decisions/isysquery/d45cf5a4-b8ed-4be0-a13e-2e3b9b5e5d95/1/doc/18-496_complete_opn.pdf#xml=http://www.ca2.uscourts.gov/decisions/isysquery/d45cf5a4-b8ed-4be0-a13e-2e3b9b5e5d95/1/hilite/ …

text: SCOTUS also declined to take up the appeal of the Christian owners of a bed and breakfast in Hawaii who were found to have violated anti-discrimination law by turning away a lesbian couple.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
SCOTUS declines to take up case of a death row inmate. 

J. Sotomayor agrees with the denial, but writes separately to note that she is "profoundly troubled" by the evidence that a juror was biased on account of race. 

That opinion is at bottom here: https://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/031819zor_c07d.pdf …
author: gabrielmalor

text: SCOTUS has also agreed to hear argument about whether the 8th and 14th Amendments permit a state to abolish the insanity defense.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
SCOTUS agrees to hear argument about whether Lee Boyd Malvo's life sentences in Virginia should be thrown out. 

The 4th Cir. had held that SCOTUS' subsequent decisions holding that juveniles could not be sentenced to life without the possibility of parole applied retroactively.

text: It's not something either Buttigieg or people writing about him should feel like apologizing about.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Folks, you don't have to say he's "openly gay" like it's 1989, and you're reassuring your readers that it's okay to say he's gay because he's out. 

It's 2019; you can just say he's gay.
author: gabrielmalor

text: Also, in the age of the quote-tweet, it's unnecessary. Lest you have any doubt what someone is saying, you can just quote-tweet them and respond. Recharacterizing what they're saying is just an easy way to deliberately miss the point and, often, be smug about it too.
author: gabrielmalor

text: This "so you're saying" manner of argument on Twitter is so common, and never helpful. In almost every case, no, that is not what anyone was saying.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
First, anyone writing "so [recharacterize your argument]" is not arguing in good faith. I did not say DOJ norms were greater than democratic norms. 

Second, the mischaracterization is stupid. There was an election. Trump won. There are constitutional means to remove him.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
The fact that impeachment and removal has atrophied as a substantive protection against bad presidents does not provide an excuse for changing DOJ rules to ignore separation of powers. 

In short: as crappy as he is, he won and there are constitutional methods for removing him.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
And, again, changing the rules now would vindicate Trump's argument that he is the victim of a Deep State apparatus that will toss aside all norms in its zeal to overturn the election.

There is a constitutional method for removing presidents.
author: gabrielmalor

text: The "easy answer" posited here runs afoul of the speedy trial and due process clauses. It puts an indicted president in the position of having to decide whether to waive constitutional protections in order to carry on with his presidency. It's a recipe for blackmail.
author: gabrielmalor

text: I was thinking about this as I RTed it. It's the punch a Nazi thing again, but I still think the kid will be proud of this. And, of course, the senator is, in fact, a vicious moron.

text: And also, let's be clear, they didn't merely yell at Clinton. They accused her of inciting terrorism against Muslims. That's a heinous accusation regardless of whether Clinton has power and influence.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Ms. Feinberg is a space-time anomaly. It is impossible for her to be wrong about absolutely everything. At some point she should get something right, even by accident, but there is just no evidence for it. 

No, it is not okay to yell at random people who did you no harm.

text: Like other recent establishment clause decisions, the panel notes that SCOTUS hasn't actually used the Lemon Test in decades, but notes that until SCOTUS explicitly overturns it, it is bound to apply it.
author: gabrielmalor

text:
Lawgeeks, here's the 7th Cir. decision upholding the constitutionality of tax-exempt housing allowances for ministers. 

Court analyzes the law under the Lemon Test and the “historical significance” test of Town of Greece v. Galloway. http://media.ca7.uscourts.gov/cgi-bin/rssExec.pl?Submit=Display&Path=Y2019/D03-15/C:18-1277:J:Brennan:aut:T:fnOp:N:2309032:S:0 …

text:
Arkansas men accused of using excessive force on youths at their juvenile detention facility have been sentenced for civil rights violations. 

2.5 years in prison for jailer, 3 years for a supervisor. Sentencing for the boss lady has been delayed.

text: Well, I'll make a statement: I don't think I've ever heard of an applicant who got a lawyer off the pro bono hand-out.
author: gabrielmalor

text: The answer to your serious question is no, and that's absurd.
author: gabrielmalor

text: You're precious.
author: gabrielmalor

text: Second problem: Payment. Lawyers like to get paid, and it's really hard to get someone who has been deported to pay. That's why the business is primarily on a a fee-for-service model. But how is somebody stuck in Mexico gonna pay their U.S.-based lawyer?
author: gabrielmalor

text:
I don't see how this is going to work. Immigration lawyers get new cases mostly by word-of-mouth referrals. Someone in their church or neighborhood 
 or in detention says, "hey, so-and-so was my lawyer." 

You're not gonna get that while you're stuck in Mexico. That's one prob.
author: gabrielmalor

text: 11th Cir.: no QI for police officer accused of overtightly zip-tying a mans hands and leaving him that way for five hours, which led to nerve damage and permanent loss of sensation. http://media.ca11.uscourts.gov/opinions/pub/files/201714751.pdf …

text:
9th Cir.: a one-year expulsion did not violate the right to free speech of a student who wrote a kill list of other students in his journal. 

His mom found the list, told a therapist, who told the police, who told the school. http://cdn.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2019/03/14/17-35500.pdf …
